perturbation.original_text: VOTOCAST shall provide sixty (60) days prior written notice to Licensee of any proposed change or modification by VOTOCAST to the Services that will materially affect Licensee or Licensee Users' use of, or ability to use. the Services.
perturbation.changed_text: VOTOCAST shall provide thirty (30) days prior written notice to Licensee of any proposed change or modification by VOTOCAST to the Services that will materially affect Licensee or Licensee Users' use of, or ability to use. the Services.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the notification period for significant service changes from 60 days to 30 days may violate California's consumer protection laws requiring reasonable notice for changes that substantially impact service usage. California law generally favors consumer rights and longer notification periods.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Consumer Rights Act, Cal. Civ. Code ยง 1750 et seq.

perturbation.original_text: All fees are due and payable within thirty (30) days of the applicable VOTOCAST invoice. Any payments made later than the due date will accrue interest from the date due until the date paid at the rate of one percent (I%) per month on the amount due, or the maximum rate permitted by law, whichever is less. In addition, failure of Licensee to fully pay any fees within sixty (60) days after the applicable due date, shall be deemed a material breach of this Agreement, justifying suspension of the performance of Services by VOTOCAST, and will be sufficient cause for immediate termination of this Agreement by VOTOCAST.
perturbation.changed_text: All fees are due and payable within fifteen (15) days of the applicable VOTOCAST invoice. Any payments made later than the due date will accrue interest from the date due until the date paid at the rate of two percent (2%) per month on the amount due, or the maximum rate permitted by law, whichever is less. In addition, failure of Licensee to fully pay any fees within thirty (30) days after the applicable due date, shall be deemed a material breach of this Agreement, justifying suspension of the performance of Services by VOTOCAST, and will be sufficient cause for immediate termination of this Agreement by VOTOCAST.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the payment timeframe to 15 days and reducing the grace period before termination to 30 days, while increasing the interest rate to 2% may be considered unconscionable or violate California's fair business practices, especially if it places undue burden on the Licensee. California law scrutinizes contract terms that are excessively one-sided or oppressive.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Commercial Code, Cal. Com. Code ยง 2302 (Unconscionable Contract or Clause)

perturbation.original_text: These confidentiality obligations shall survive for three (3) years after expiration or termination of this Agreement; provided, that the expiration of such obligations shall not affect any other restrictions on the Recipient, including without limitation, any restrictions under patent or copyright laws.
perturbation.changed_text: These confidentiality obligations shall survive for one (1) year after expiration or termination of this Agreement; provided, that the expiration of such obligations shall not affect any other restrictions on the Recipient, including without limitation, any restrictions under patent or copyright laws.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the confidentiality period from three years to one year might be problematic. Given that the agreement is based in California, a one-year confidentiality period could be deemed insufficient to adequately protect trade secrets or sensitive business information, especially considering the rapid pace of technological advancements. California's Uniform Trade Secrets Act provides protections for an undefined time (as long as it is a secret), which conflicts with this one-year term.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Uniform Trade Secrets Act, Cal. Civ. Code ยง 3426 et seq.
